Dinner Rolls

Jump to Recipe

Are you ready to elevate your dinner experience with irresistible, homemade dinner rolls? The soft, fluffy texture and the rich buttery flavor of these rolls will make them the star of your meal, whether you're serving them alongside a hearty stew, a festive holiday feast, or just a simple weeknight dinner. This easy dinner roll recipe is perfect for bakers of all skill levels, featuring basic ingredients like all-purpose flour, instant yeast, and warm water. In just a few simple steps, you can create a batch of freshly baked rolls that are sure to impress family and friends alike. Plus, the delightful aroma wafting through your kitchen as they bake is simply unbeatable! Follow along as we guide you through this straightforward process, and soon you'll be pulling warm, golden-brown rolls from your oven, ready to enjoy with butter or as the perfect addition to any meal. Let's get started!

Ingredients

all-purpose flour

All-purpose flour is the standard choice for dinner rolls, providing a good balance of protein for structure and tenderness. For a lighter texture, consider using bread flour, which has a higher protein content. If you prefer a gluten-free option, substitute with a 1:1 gluten-free flour blend, but be sure to check for additional binding agents such as xanthan gum.

warm water

Ensure the water is warm (about 110°F or 43°C) to activate the yeast effectively. If it's too hot, it can kill the yeast; if too cold, it won't activate. You can also use milk instead of water for a richer flavor, but make sure to warm the milk as well.

instant yeast

Instant yeast is great for quick rises and doesn't require proofing. If substituting with active dry yeast, increase the amount to 2 1/4 teaspoons and proof it in the warm water with sugar before adding it to the dough. Always store yeast in a cool, dry place, and check its expiration date for best results.

sugar

Sugar not only adds sweetness but also helps to feed the yeast, enhancing the rise. For a healthier alternative, you can use honey or maple syrup, but reduce the liquid in the recipe slightly to maintain consistency.

salt

Salt is crucial for flavor but also regulates yeast activity. If you're watching your sodium intake, you can reduce the amount slightly, but don't omit it entirely, as it enhances the overall taste.

unsalted butter

Unsalted butter allows you to control the salt level in your recipe. If you don't have unsalted, you can use salted butter but reduce the added salt in the recipe by about half. For a dairy-free version, substitute with coconut oil or a plant-based butter.

milk

Milk adds richness and moisture to dinner rolls. You can substitute with non-dairy milk such as almond or soy milk for a lactose-free option. If using a non-dairy milk, choose an unsweetened variety to avoid adding extra sugar.

egg

The egg adds moisture, richness, and helps with the structure of the rolls. If you're looking for a vegan alternative, you can use a flaxseed meal (1 tablespoon flaxseed mixed with 3 tablespoons water, let sit until thickened) or 1/4 cup applesauce as a binding agent.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Activate Yeast

    In a large bowl, combine 1 cup of warm water (about 110°F or 43°C), 2 tablespoons of sugar, and 2 tablespoons of instant yeast. Stir gently and let it sit for 5 minutes until it becomes frothy. This indicates that your yeast is alive and ready to leaven the bread.

  • Step 2: Combine Wet Ingredients

    To the yeast mixture, add 4 tablespoons of melted unsalted butter, 1/4 cup of milk, and 1 egg. Stir until all the ingredients are well combined. The milk and butter will add richness to the rolls.

  • Step 3: Mix Dry Ingredients

    In a separate bowl, combine 3 cups of all-purpose flour and 1 teaspoon of salt. Slowly add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture, stirring with a wooden spoon or spatula until a rough dough forms.

  • Step 4: Knead the Dough

    Transfer the dough onto a floured surface. Knead for about 5 minutes until the dough is smooth and elastic. If the dough sticks to your hands, sprinkle a little more flour. This step is crucial for developing gluten, which gives the rolls structure.

  • Step 5: First Rise

    Place the kneaded dough into a greased bowl, turning it to coat the surface with oil. Cover with a clean kitchen towel and let it rise in a warm place for 1 hour or until it has doubled in size. A warm, draft-free environment is ideal for rising.

  • Step 6: Preheat Oven

    While the dough is rising, preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C). This ensures that the rolls will cook evenly once they are placed in the oven.

  • Step 7: Shape the Rolls

    After the dough has risen, punch it down to release the air. Divide it into 12 equal pieces. Shape each piece into a smooth ball and place them in a greased baking dish, leaving a little space between each roll to allow for further rising.

  • Step 8: Second Rise

    Cover the shaped rolls with a towel and let them rise for another 30 minutes. This final rise will ensure that the rolls are fluffy and light.

  • Step 9: Bake the Rolls

    Once the rolls have risen, place them in the preheated oven and bake for 15-20 minutes or until they are golden brown on top. Keep an eye on them to avoid over-baking.

  • Step 10: Brush with Butter

    After removing the rolls from the oven, brush the tops with melted butter for added flavor and shine. Allow them to cool slightly before serving.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I measure flour accurately?

To measure flour accurately, spoon it into your measuring cup without packing it down, then level it off with a straight edge. This ensures you don't use too much flour, which can make your rolls dense.

What is the purpose of letting the yeast mixture sit until frothy?

Letting the yeast mixture sit activates the yeast, which is essential for rising. The frothy appearance indicates that the yeast is alive and ready to help your dough rise.

How can I tell if my dough has risen enough?

After 1 hour, your dough should have doubled in size. You can test it by gently pressing your finger into the dough; if it holds the indentation, it's ready.

What should I do if my kitchen is cold and the dough won’t rise?

If your kitchen is cold, you can create a warm environment by preheating the oven to the lowest setting for a couple of minutes, then turning it off. Place the dough inside, covered with a towel, to help it rise.

How do I know when the rolls are done baking?

The rolls are done when they are golden brown on top and sound hollow when tapped on the bottom. You can also use a thermometer; they should reach an internal temperature of about 190°F (88°C).

Can I use active dry yeast instead of instant yeast?

Yes, you can use active dry yeast instead of instant yeast, but you'll need to activate it in warm water with sugar for about 10 minutes before adding it to the mixture.

What can I do with leftover dinner rolls?

Leftover dinner rolls can be stored in an airtight container for a few days or frozen for up to three months. Simply reheat them in the oven before serving.

Is it necessary to brush the rolls with butter before serving?

Brushing the rolls with melted butter adds flavor and keeps the tops soft. While it's not necessary, it enhances the overall taste and appearance of your dinner rolls.

How can I tell if my dough is kneaded enough?

Dough is kneaded enough when it is smooth and elastic. You can perform the 'windowpane test' by stretching a small piece; if it stretches thin without tearing, it’s ready.

What is the best way to store and reheat the rolls?

Store the rolls at room temperature in an airtight container. To reheat, wrap them in foil and warm in the oven at 350°F (175°C) for about 10 minutes to keep them soft.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a gluten-free version, substitute all-purpose flour with a gluten-free flour blend designed for baking. To make these dinner rolls dairy-free, replace the unsalted butter with a dairy-free alternative like coconut oil or vegan butter, and use almond or oat milk instead of regular milk. If you wish to avoid eggs, you can use a flaxseed meal or chia seed mixture as an egg replacer (1 tablespoon of flaxseed meal mixed with 2.5 tablespoons of water, let sit until gelatinous).

Pairings

Serve the dinner rolls warm with a variety of accompaniments such as creamy butter, garlic herb spread, or even a drizzle of honey for sweetness. These rolls pair beautifully with hearty soups like butternut squash or chicken noodle, as well as roasted meats such as herb-crusted chicken or beef brisket. For beverages, consider pairing with a light red wine like Pinot Noir or a crisp white wine such as Sauvignon Blanc.

Serving Suggestions

To enhance the dining experience, serve the rolls in a warm, bread basket lined with a clean cloth to keep them warm. For an appealing presentation, brush the tops of the rolls with melted herb-infused butter right before serving. Consider garnishing with freshly chopped herbs like parsley or rosemary for added color and aroma. For casual gatherings, arrange the rolls alongside a charcuterie board with cheeses, cured meats, and olives.

Dinner Rolls

$5

Difficulty: 30%
Servings: 12

Description

Soft, fluffy dinner rolls perfect for any meal.

Ingredients

  • all-purpose flour: 3 cups
  • warm water: 1 cup
  • instant yeast: 2 tablespoons
  • sugar: 2 tablespoons
  • salt: 1 teaspoon
  • unsalted butter: 4 tablespoons
  • milk: 1/4 cup
  • egg: 1
